The error is the following, likely trying to evaluate system properties on a pre-1.4 VM that does not have XML support (ug).

getErrorStreamMonitor().getContents()
	 (java.lang.String) java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/w3c/dom/Node
Exception in thread "main"
Fixed. When the VM is pre 1.4, I just create text that looks like an XML file rather than using the XML support. Added "LegacySystemProperties" and Changes to AbstractVMInstall.
Please verify, Kevin.
*** Bug 124461 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
verified

Note that there is a spelling mistake in the error message.

 Unable to retreive system properties

Should be:

 Unable to retrieve system properties
Fixed spelling error in HEAD

Installed JREs

I have the same problem (log messages, empty Execution Environments) in I20060125-0800. I exported my installed JREs and a tried to reproduce with a fresh workspace with only these JREs and a dummy plugin, but there it worked without problems. I guess it is a timing issue, and not an issue with the installed JREs.

I also don't have the problem if I switch to the (unmodified) Resources perspective before restarting eclipse. However, I get it again after I shut down while the Java or Debug perspective is open.

>I guess it is a timing issue
Might be, see also bug 125297.

I'm having the same problem with the only installed JRE being a 1.5.0 one

(In reply to comment #7)
> Fixed spelling error in HEAD
I still get the spelling mistake and the problem using I20060125-0800
We did not contribute to the re-build. The fix is in HEAD.

>We did not contribute to the re-build. The fix is in HEAD.
You mean the fix for the spelling problem, right?
Correct :-) The spelling problem is fixed in HEAD, not the "unable to retrieve system properties" problem.

Just give me a note if you need help in reproducing or tracking this down. I can reliably reproduce it by shutting down when my (customized) Debug perspective is open.

It looks like the Debug Event Dispatch job is only scheduled but never started when this problem occurs.

Markus, I just released new code to HEAD that simplifies the "wait for system property eval" code. Could you please try it?

It does not address a problem of debug event dispatch. We schedule the job, but we are not responsible for starting it. Our shouldRun/Schedule code looks reasonable.

Created an attachment (id=33729)
stdout log

I tried it with org.eclipse.jdt.launching from HEAD. I don't get the exceptions any more, but there's a 3+ minutes pause after the "Debug Event Dispatch" job has been scheduled. I'll append the complete stdout of the startup sequence with org.eclipse.core.jobs debug options /jobs, /jobs/timing, /jobs/beginend enabled.

I pressed Ctrl+Break twice during the long wait, in order to see who's waiting.
The "worker sleeping for: 60000ms" messages after the stacktraces needed about a minute each until the next one came in.

John, is there any reason a scheduled job would not run immediately? According to Markus, the reason this bug occurrs in his environment is that the job to fire debug events is not run until after our "wait for terminate" has timed out. I can't reproduce, but this also sounds like the problem in bug 125297.

I have now seen this once. It happenned when the splash screen was up and execution environments were being computed. When I tried again, the problem did not occurr (but environments were computed after the workbenc appeared in that case). Not sure if there is a difference when running jobs when the spash screen is present vs. workbench window, or if something in the job queue was ahead of/preventing the debug event dispatch from running.

I saw this again, and once again, only when the splash screen was up. I've released a workaround to the problem that does not rely on debug events. Still want to learn why the disptach job is not running.
*** Bug 125297 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Fixed. The workaround will be the solution, as jobs are suspended during startup (did not know that).
Please verify, Kevin.
verified
